comments.body: Make sure to vote for yourself.
I honestly love the idea. The recipe should be 1 Torch and 8 Paper surrounding the item. That's just my thought though.
Paper lanterns are always welcome! Maybe there could be a slight recipe change or a simple choice to let the crafter either hang it, or let it float into the air.
Though it would a small change it would definitely help when building towns because you see a lot of bell towers.
YES! That would be sooooo cool! I think maybe you should even be on fire for a second, that would be funny! Also maybe you could stop it by drinking a bottle of water!

Translation:

The idea is to add to the game a knife on which you can apply various effects with potions. (I want to apologize for using Google translator) 

Each knife will have a chance to ‚Äúbreak‚Äù the enemy‚Äôs armor. 
Here is the table: 
stone knife: leather armor - 40% iron armor - 20% chain mail armor - 15% Diamond armor - 10% gold armor - 5% 
iron knife: leather armor - 80% iron armor - 40% armor - 30% Diamond armor - 15% armor bonus - 10% 
gold knife: leather armor - 60% iron armor - 30% chain mail armor -20% Diamond armor - 40% armor bonus - 10% Diamond knife: Leather armor - 100% iron armor - 70% chain mail mail - 60% Diamond armor - 30% gold armor - 15%
Emerald knife: leather armor - 100% iron armor - 90% chain mail armor - 80% Diamond armor - 60% armor bonus - 30% 
and only some effects will be available for knives: 
stone - 1 iron - 2 gold, 5 diamonds - 3 Emerald - 4 (the ability to use the "golden apple" (2 cells)) 

This will diversify the gameplay and add another interesting

Puting 8 string and one dye into the crafting box should give you 8 colored string.

This is an awesome idea since string is so hard to see as is. I know Grian was struggling when using it to prevent snow on his build in hermitcraft, but regardless, it would be awesome to use it for finer details on builds too

I think colored string could also be useful when it comes to traps! Sometimes, it's pretty easier to spot the white string on the ground, but if it was a color other than white (one that would better blend into its surroundings), you could catch quite a few unobservant players by surprise.
Like a golden. Lasso
That would be nice
or just make all banners have 12 patterns. I mean like theres no reason not to lol.
THAT SOUNDS AWESOME!!!!!!

I think this would be a cool idea but i think u need something to hold it so its a late game. Maybe u need to craft it first like a conduit so maybe the crafting will be the same as the beacon but instead of the nether star the middle is the guardian's eye and it will be called Controlled Guardian's eye or something
Could you also please make it a recipe for a Mining Fatigue Potion?

I dont consider to add the potion because 1. Its expensive just for a potion and 2. Either it is a potion, throwing someone w/ that potion will problably affects you too (bcs is splash). But if a potion of it really be suggested and added maybe thats useful for pvp like bedwars?
I could see how it could be expensive though because it dramatically decrease the players attack/mining speeds.

Its worth making for pvp reasons, but mining fatigue will not be useful for singleplayer though, but the effect still can be obtained via commands and if they adding mining fatigue potion it will be exclusive potions that can only get via commands like potion of wither, luck, nausea, etc

I think other blocks should be able to let smoke pass through them too, like iron bars, fence posts, and leaves
I think they would've put this in.
I love the idea.
Absolutely! I went snorkeling and my brother got stung! It would serve as a warning of fire coral's dangers in real life
I mean extinguishing a Campfire isn't that hard to do.
It's also suppose to be an easy way for players to get cooked food when they start a new world.
It honestly does make sense because you're rubbing the stick together to make a Campfire even though it doesn't display that.
Perhaps the unlit campfire should be a block in and of itself.

I do get why mojang perhaps wanted it lit by default, so it can be used right away and one does not need to obtain flint and steel to light it up. But, if one already have acces to coal (that is needed for the crafting of the campfire) then one can as easily craft a furnace and use the coal there.

Personally I would like the campfire unlit by default, it would make it easier to use for builders who use it as a decorative piece, since it is often used quite a lot in builds.

I do also believe it is used more often in its unlit form than its lit form so in that regard, it also makes more sense having it unlit by default.
This would be a considerable improvement for Survival builders, as the (unlit) campfire is a great block aesthetically but a pain to extinguish en-masse.

In general this seems like a good idea, but I found a problem:

 

Following the same logic, shouldn't torches apply too?

That would be very annoying to have to light torches, so that's why we don't have to.

But if campfires had to be lit, it would create an inconsistency.
I mean, that would make logical sense.

sounds sick!
I really like this Idea.

I could easily see this being used for land vehicles, aircraft, boats and even possibly mechs.  A few more additional block types might need to be added to fully flesh this out but this sounds like a great idea!

Easy crafting recipe for this would be two of the bricks(B) from smelting clay and two nether bricks(N).
{B,N}
{N,B}
This honestly is too similar to an Anvil and a Grindstone. That's my opinion though.

I was going to make a similar post.  I was thinking you could also add a slot on the cartography table to place item frames to upgrade them.  An upgraded item frame would become a map frame.  Map frames would just look like a white screen and take up the whole block face.  You'd place them on the wall in a grid.  When you placed any map on them it would display correctly relative to other maps you'd clicked on the larger grid of map frames (if it would fit within the range).

Alternately, you could have a button to click in the cartography table to switch to a grid view in the table and you could place the table and it would put them in the correct position and allow you to make a bigger map.  You could link the map frames to the table and they would display the maps in the table.  To avoid weird shape maps (2x1s, for instance) it could require you put more blank maps in to fill a grid.  It would also be nice if you could put blank maps in a grid in the table and it would assign them to specific areas... so say you do a 3x3 grid of blank maps each map would be assigned to one section of that grid, even although it's not already filled in.  This could help prevent accidentally clicking a map in an area you already have a map for.

Treasure maps of the same area should really be stackable or at least made so via a cartography table. More generally, it would be quite helpful if you could use a cartography table to combine the populated details of 2 non-identical but overlapping maps. Eg1: you've accidentally got 2 maps of the same area with different parts filled in, you'd be able to make them identical and stackable. Eg2: you want to replicate the filled-in details from a low-scale map to a higher-scale map that encompasses that area (or vice versa I suppose).
Possibly monster jerky could be brewed to make something
This would be genius hopefully they implement it.
Eating monster jerky should restore 5 (üçóüçóüçó) hunger and 6.0 hunger saturation, which is equal to bread. Also, Mojang could work with Jack Links to sell this in real life.
This is a great idea! I used to fence myself, so I am a little biased. The only thing I see missing is a parry. Perhaps the Larry should be right click and backdash be S+SHIFT?

I'd vote for creating the Rapier via the Smithing Table, especially in case players expect multiple different kinds of swords to be featured. It could also use the same jabbing ability that the Spear from the Mounts of Mayhem has which replaces the standard swing mechanic.
This would make it so much easier to identify fireworks in storage!

Agreed, even if it wasn't fully accurate because of the many variations that can be done with fireworks, If it just had a main color shift to give basic distinctions it would be easier to visually identify one firework from another.
Should be able to just dye them, that way it‚Äôs user decided.
Why an enchanting table?  I think an anvil should be used instead.

@William Miller, Because an Enchanting table is magic. Endless possibilities about it. The enchanted particles can be merged with Dyes. Apparently, you can extract dyes into tint colors using a magic source. Both Hammer and Anvil are both just physical. It would make stains on the sword, bypassing the enchanted particles. Magic particles can convert a regular dye to a rune dye, and the rune dyes can change a enchanted particles' color. Science of magic.
By that logic, anvils shouldn't be used to combine two items, because it doesn't make sense to pound one sword into another to make it more powerful.

I think we can take advantage of the Smithing Table for this.  Currently its only use is to upgrade Diamond to Netherite, which doesn't make a lick of sense anyway.  Maybe create another item for an enchantment specific dye?  Off the top of my head:

Glowstone Dust + Dye
Maybe call it something like Pixie Dust.  Could also be used the same way as redstone but for artistic patterns, like sidewalk chalk.

Enchanting Table: Book + Dye
Replace the lapis on an enchantment table with a dye and create some kind of Tome of Color.  Maybe it comes with actual enchants, maybe all it does is recolor the enchant effect.

Enchanting Table: Replace Lapis with Dye
Cutting out the middleman as it were.  Instead of requiring lapis as the magical element, require dye.
